posts.name: Alexis
posts.cooked: I joined a new team recently and they use Fusion. I‚Äôm familiar with Inventor and somewhat with Onshape, and I‚Äôm trying to learn Fusion. Any users have any good tips on learning?

posts.name: Brad Billeaudeau FRC Team 4206
posts.cooked:
The 100 days of fusion exercises are a pretty good start.

Each image is linked to the YouTube video for that day (just click the image!)

posts.name: Neel M
posts.cooked: If you are familiar with onshape, i found it very useful to go into preferneces and change my option for cad software to ‚Äútinker cad‚Äù, and then edit some of my keybinds to match onshapes. I‚Äôve found myself to be very efficient with this, and was able to pick up fusion relatively quickly

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
Loki:

If you are familiar with onshape, i found it very useful to go into preferneces and change my option for cad software to ‚Äútinker cad‚Äù

If you are only using Fusion 360 for CAM with Onshape CAD, you‚Äôll save yourself some brain strain if you change your pan, zoom, orbit shortcuts to Tinkercad to be compatible with Onshape.  If you are trying to fully convert to Fusion 360, you may be better off in the long run by paying the price to remap your brain to the default Fusion controls.

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked: I‚Äôve found that Fusion 360 can be easier to learn than Onshape. There are many tutorials out there but my best suggestion is to use what you know already and just get your hands dirty. Try clicking around and seeing/figuring out what things do and if you get stumped, turn to YouTube. Approching CAD this way can be a great way to learn skills more deeply than just following a tutorial.
